Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited Reports Earnings Results for the Second Quarter and Six Months Ended September 30, 2025
data.description:
Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited reported earnings results for the second quarter and six months ended September 30, 2025. For the second quarter, the company reported sales was INR 1,216,047 million compared to INR 1,179,487.5 million a year ago. Revenue was INR 1,225,574.7 million compared to INR 1,186,462 million a year ago. Net income was INR 61,914.9 million compared to INR 22,972.3 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was INR 14.49 compared to INR 5.38 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was INR 14.49 compared to INR 5.38 a year ago.
For the six months, sales was INR 2,512,193.9 million compared to INR 2,460,551.4 million a year ago. Revenue was INR 2,529,218.7 million compared to INR 2,473,230.8 million a year ago. Net income was INR 130,305.1 million compared to INR 51,387.8 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was INR 30.5 compared to INR 12.03 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was INR 30.5 compared to INR 12.03 a year ago.

data.title: Imperial Oil 3Q Profit Slides on Higher Costs; Output Up
data.description:
By Adriano Marchese


Imperial Oil's third quarter profit fell on one-off impairment and restructuring costs in the third quarter, while revenue rose on the back of higher oil production.

The Canadian energy company posted a lower net income of 539 million Canadian dollars ($385.3 million), or C$1.07 a share, down from C$1.24 billion, or C$2.33 a share, in the comparable quarter a year ago.

The company said the decline was due primarily to a non-cash impairment of the Calgary Imperial Campus and a previously-announced restructuring charge.

According to FactSet, analysts were expecting C$1.96 a share.

Total revenue fell to C$12.05 billion from C$13.26 billion, missing forecasts of only a slighter decrease to C$13.16 billion.

Upstream production averaged 462,000 gross oil-equivalent barrels a day, up from 447,000 barrels a day a year earlier, thanks largely to the company's Kearl oil sands operations in Fort McMurray, Alberta.

Refinery throughput averaged 425,000 barrels per day, up from 389,000 barrels per day.

Imperial Oil noted that the price of crude oil increased slightly relative to the previous quarter.


Write to Adriano Marchese at adriano.marchese@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 0850ET

data.title: LG Electronics' Net Attributable Income Jumps in Q3, Sales Marginally Down
Dr. Lal PathLabs' Fiscal Q2 Profit Rises; Declares Second Interim Dividend
ExxonMobil: Q3 EPS up 15%
data.description:
ExxonMobil has reported Q3 2025 earnings of $7.55bn, or $1.76 per share. Non-GAAP EPS rose nearly 15% sequentially to $1.88, exceeding the consensus.

"We achieved the highest EPS we have ever recorded in a similar oil price environment," said CEO Darren Woods, pointing to record production in Guyana and the Permian Basin.

ExxonMobil reported operating cash flow of $14.8bn and distributed $9.4bn to shareholders, including $4.2bn in dividends and $5.1bn in share repurchases, in line with announced plans.

Having exceeded $14bn in cumulative structural cost savings since 2019, including $2.2bn achieved in 2025, the oil and gas group says it is on track to achieve over $18bn by the end of 2030.

data.title: Chevron: Q3 EPS up 4%
data.description:
Chevron has reported adjusted net income of $3.63bn for Q3 2025, or $1.85 per share, EPS that is up nearly 4% over the previous quarter, exceeding analysts' expectations.

These results reflect record production, strong cash generation and sustained cash returns to shareholders, management said, adding that the integration of Hess is progressing well, unlocking synergies.

Compared to the same period in 2024, Chevron's production rose 27% in the US and 21% globally in Q3, reaching record levels, while its adjusted free cash flow increased over 50% to $7bn.

The energy group added that it distributed $6bn in cash to its shareholders during the past quarter, bringing the total distributed over the last three years to more than $78bn.

data.title: London stocks ease after recent rally; focus shifts to budget, Bank of England
Solidity confirmed, Intesa Sanpaolo meets ECB requirements
data.description:
(Alliance News) - Intesa Sanpaolo received the ECB's final decision on Friday on the capital requirements to be met from January 1, 2026, following the supervisory review and evaluation process known as SREP. The institution will have to maintain a consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 ratio of 9.97%, a level that takes into account both the minimum Pillar 1 capital requirement, set at 8%, and the additional Pillar 2 requirements introduced by the ECB, which bring the additional CET1 component to 0.93%.

Additional capital buffers designed to ensure stability and resilience are added to this threshold. The Capital Conservation Buffer at 2.5%, the O-SII Buffer for systemically important institutions at 1.25%, the countercyclical capital buffer at 0.34%, and the Systemic Risk Buffer at 0.45%.

Together, these requirements define the prudential framework within which the bank will have to operate in 2026, ensuring a solid capital base.

The figures updated as of September 30 confirm Intesa Sanpaolo's robustness. Net of EUR 5.3 billion in dividends accrued in the first nine months of the year and coupons on Additional Tier 1 issues for EUR 300 million, the consolidated CET1 ratio stands at 13.9%, while the Total Capital ratio reaches 19.3%.

Considering the pro forma effects, the CET1 ratio rises to 14.9% and the Total Capital ratio to 20.5%, levels significantly higher than the requirements set by the ECB.

Intesa Sanpaolo fell 1.6% to EUR5.61 per share on Friday.

By Maurizio Carta, Alliance News reporter

Comments and questions to redazione@alliancenews.com
